CHESS GRANDMASTERS

HOW THEY SEIZE CONTROL OF THE BATTLEFIELD

MAGNUS
CARLSEN

WORLD #1

RATING: 2852

Sven Magnus Ã˜en Carlsen (born 30 November 1990) is a Norwegian chess grandmaster who is the reigning five-time World Chess Champion, four-time World Rapid Chess Champion, and six-time World Blitz Chess Champion. Magnus Carlsen has held the number one position in the FIDE world chess rankings since 1 July 2011. His peak rating of 2882 is the highest in history. He also holds the record for the longest unbeaten streak at the elite level in classical chess.

PIECE ACTIVITY

The corresponding chart shows the composition of the pieces which control the observed square. Rather displaying the average value, the percentage values give the actual proportion of each piece placed on the square which counted up from all games provided as data.

Illustration is taken from a match between Magnus Carlsen (white) against Fabiano Caruana (black) in Speed Chess Championship 2022.

×

SQUARE UTILIZATION

When Magnus Carlsen competes in a game, the battle over the chessboard mostly lasts for 45.5 moves. Whilst the characteristics of the game are quite diverse in terms of strategy and placement of pieces between the white and black sides, the heatmap chart shows the overall piece movement consisting of both sides. As a result, the heatmap has a quite symmetrical shape or more precisely resembles a low slope hill. The D4 square has the most activity with a score of 1.7, which means, either playing as white or black, controlling this square is as important as maintaining safety of the king.

Illustration is taken from a match between Magnus Carlsen (white) against Sergey Slugin (black) in Titled Tuesday Blitz October 2022.

×

PIECE CAPTURE

After each game, Magnus Carlsen captures an average of 11.5 pieces from the opposing army. The corresponding bar chart shows the distribution of the average piece capture score within each respective rank on the chessboard. As the bar chart shows, the 4th rank is the bloodiest as 2.7 of opponentâ€™s pieces are taken off the board each game.

Illustration is taken from a match between Magnus Carlsen (white) against Vidit Santosh Gujrathi (black) in Meltwater Champions Chess Tour 2022.

×

ROOK PLACEMENT

On average, Magnus Carlsen moves his rooks around 8.4 moves per game. The corresponding bar chart shows the distribution of the rook placement mean score within each individual file on the chessboard. The D file is mostly under control with an average score of 2.0.

Illustration is taken from a match between Magnus Carlsen (white) against Levon Aronian (black) in Botvinnik Memorial 2011.
